+------------------------+----------------+------------------+

However, I would like to load the data from the collection directly into spark without having to read the extracted documents into a list and iterate through in java to perform the dataframe conversion. Currently though, I am only able to read in the entire collection if I read directly into spark:

SparkConf conf = new SparkConf();
    
conf.set("spark.master","local");
conf.set("spark.app.name","ExampleApp");
    
conf.set("spark.jars.packages","org.mongodb.spark:mongo-spark-connector:10.0.1");

// Set up read connection :
conf.set("spark.mongodb.read.connection.uri", "mongodb://user:password@example.com:27017");
conf.set("spark.mongodb.read.database", "ExampleDb");
conf.set("spark.mongodb.read.collection", "DataPoint");

// Set up write connection
conf.set("spark.mongodb.write.connection.uri", "mongodb://user:password@example.com:27017");
conf.set("spark.mongodb.write.database", "ExampleDb");
conf.set("spark.mongodb.write.collection", "DataPoint");

SparkContext context = new SparkContext(conf);
SparkSession spark = SparkSession.builder().sparkContext(context).getOrCreate();

Dataset<Row> dataset = spark.read().format("mongodb").load().select(col("_id"), col("lat"), col("lon"));
dataset.withColumn("lat", dataset.col("lat").cast("float"));
dataset.withColumn("lon", dataset.col("lon").cast("float"));
dataset.na().drop();
dataset.printSchema();
dataset.show(false);

My questions are:

What is the most efficient way of reading the desired data into Spark? Should the entire collection be loaded, the repository methods above scrapped, and Spark's functions used to perform the filtering instead, or is there a away to apply mongo's geo functions to the read?
If the former, is there an efficient way to compare lat/lon doubles to a predefined geo polygon and only keep rows in the dataframe where the coordinates lie inside?

Or, if is still better to keep the repository methods above, is there a more efficient way to convert the list into a dataframe?

If the answer depends on the volume of data, then I'd certainly want to entertain both approaches and run performance tests myself.

answers.title: How to make `Map::get` return either an `Optional` of the found value or `Optional.empty()`
answers.body:
Why not simply:

return Optional.ofNullable(myMap.get(myKey));

JavaDocs

answers.body_markdown:
This

    Optional.of(myMap.getOrDefault(myKey, null));

or really

    Optional.of(null);

would've failed with a `NullPointerException`. As the [javadoc][1] states

> Throws:  
> **NullPointerException** - if `value` is null


[`Optional#ofNullable`][2] exists when you don't know if the value you're passing to it is `null` or not:

> **Parameters**:  
> `value` - the possibly-null value to describe

And since [`Map#get(Object)`][3] already returns `null` when there is no entry for the given key

> **Returns**:  
> the value to which the specified key is mapped, or `null` if
> this map contains no mapping for the key

you don't need to use `getOrDefault` with a `null` value for the default. You can instead directly use

    Optional.ofNullable(myMap.get(myKey));


  [1]: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/10/docs/api/java/util/Optional.html#of(T)
  [2]: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/10/docs/api/java/util/Optional.html#ofNullable(T)
  [3]: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/10/docs/api/java/util/Map.html#get(java.lang.Object)
answers.title: How to make `Map::get` return either an `Optional` of the found value or `Optional.empty()`
answers.body:
This

Optional.of(myMap.getOrDefault(myKey, null));

or really

Optional.of(null);

would've failed with a NullPointerException. As the javadoc states

Throws:
NullPointerException - if value is null

Optional#ofNullable exists when you don't know if the value you're passing to it is null or not:

Parameters:
value - the possibly-null value to describe

And since Map#get(Object) already returns null when there is no entry for the given key

Returns:
the value to which the specified key is mapped, or null if this map contains no mapping for the key

you don't need to use getOrDefault with a null value for the default. You can instead directly use

Optional.ofNullable(myMap.get(myKey));

answers.body_markdown:
Functional and definitely too long solution:
```
myMap.entrySet().stream()
  .filter(it -> it.getKey().equals(myKey))
  .findFirst()
  .map(Map.Entry::getValue);
```
answers.title: How to make `Map::get` return either an `Optional` of the found value or `Optional.empty()`
answers.body:
Functional and definitely too long solution:

myMap.entrySet().stream()
  .filter(it -> it.getKey().equals(myKey))
  .findFirst()
  .map(Map.Entry::getValue);

answers.body_markdown:
If the map contains a null value, the `Optional.ofNullable(...)` solution won't work. You need to do something like:

```java
myMap.containsKey(myKey) ? Optional.of(myMap.get(myKey)) : Optional.empty();
```

It's annoying to have to check the map twice, but there doesn't seem to be a better way.
answers.title: How to make `Map::get` return either an `Optional` of the found value or `Optional.empty()`
answers.body:
If the map contains a null value, the Optional.ofNullable(...) solution won't work. You need to do something like:

myMap.containsKey(myKey) ? Optional.of(myMap.get(myKey)) : Optional.empty();

It's annoying to have to check the map twice, but there doesn't seem to be a better way.

class AccountingJournalLineItemServiceTest : AbstractAccountingUnitTest() {

     // Other mocks

        every { // Here error occurs
            moneyCalculator.sum(emptyList<AccountingJournalLineMoney>())
        } returns Money(
            creditAmount = BigDecimal.ZERO,
            debitAmount = BigDecimal.ZERO,
            currency = Currency.AED
        )

        val actual = service.getJournalLinesAsResponsePayload(
            "company".Id,
            "sync".Id,
            mockk()
        )
    }

}



open class AbstractAccountingUnitTest {

    protected val companyId = "company".Id
    protected val regularCycleId = "regularCycle".Id
    protected val synchronizationId = "synchronization".Id

    @BeforeEach
    open fun setup() {
        MockKAnnotations.init(this)
    }
}

items.title: How to resolve a required class was missing while executing : java/sql/SQLException
items.body:
